content.raw: @{mabelmzhang} , can you remind me why it's necessary to pass the compress path to `ServerConfig` and propagate it all the way to the plugin, instead of just appending the `.zip` directly at `LogRecord.cc`?
content.html: @Mabel Zhang , can you remind me why it's necessary to pass the compress path to ServerConfig and propagate it all the way to the plugin, instead of just appending the .zip directly at LogRecord.cc?

content.raw: I just saw this comment below, I guess this is the underlying reason: "used to check for duplicates"
content.html: I just saw this comment below, I guess this is the underlying reason: "used to check for duplicates"

content.raw:
Yeah, it’s a bit tricky with some combination of existing files. For example if `something` doesn’t exist, but `something(1).zip` exists, then we want it to record to `something(2)` directory and write to `something(2).zip`. So it has to go back and rename the directory name too. It covers most cases.

A case it does not cover is that it could rename the directory, then the zip, then the new named directory exists, and then it should really go back to rename the directory - it doesn’t do that right now. I can think of a concrete example when I have a bit more time but I have seen it happen with the latest code. I thought it would be too ugly to go back and rename the directory and the zip a 3rd time.
content.html:
Yeah, it’s a bit tricky with some combination of existing files. For example if something doesn’t exist, but something(1).zip exists, then we want it to record to something(2) directory and write to something(2).zip. So it has to go back and rename the directory name too. It covers most cases.

A case it does not cover is that it could rename the directory, then the zip, then the new named directory exists, and then it should really go back to rename the directory - it doesn’t do that right now. I can think of a concrete example when I have a bit more time but I have seen it happen with the latest code. I thought it would be too ugly to go back and rename the directory and the zip a 3rd time.

content.raw:
Gotcha, thanks. If you can look into the 3-times-renaming case that would be nice.

Since we're keeping the compress path, another concern is what happens if `LogRecordCompress() == true` but `LogRecordCompressPath().empty()`. Maybe one way to avoid this would be to remove the boolean flag, and consider compress to be off when the compress path is empty?
content.html:
Gotcha, thanks. If you can look into the 3-times-renaming case that would be nice.

Since we're keeping the compress path, another concern is what happens if LogRecordCompress() == true but LogRecordCompressPath().empty(). Maybe one way to avoid this would be to remove the boolean flag, and consider compress to be off when the compress path is empty?

content.raw: Removed Boolean flag in 99cea19
content.html: Removed Boolean flag in 99cea19

content.raw: The renaming could happen in a loop that checks whether either the directory or the compressed file exist, and keeps renaming until none of them do. What do you think?
content.html: The renaming could happen in a loop that checks whether either the directory or the compressed file exist, and keeps renaming until none of them do. What do you think?

content.raw:
9bb7af8 & 95c56bf

So I ended up replacing the `common::unique*()` calls with the line of logic from `unique*()`. That fixed the problem. It was needed because having two `unique()` calls separately on the directory and the file didn’t let us control the counter. So we ended up with things like `(2)(1)`.

Previously, the problem could be reproduced by:

```
ign gazebo -v 4 -r ../examples/worlds/log_record_dbl_pendulum.sdf --log-compress --log-overwrite --record-path '/tmp/log'
ign gazebo -v 4 -r ../examples/worlds/log_record_dbl_pendulum.sdf --log-compress --record-path '/tmp/log'
ign gazebo -v 4 -r ../examples/worlds/log_record_dbl_pendulum.sdf --record-path '/tmp/log'
ign gazebo -v 4 -r ../examples/worlds/log_record_dbl_pendulum.sdf --log-compress --record-path '/tmp/log'
```

which produces:

```
$ ls /tmp
'log(1).zip'
'log(2)'
'log(2)(1).zip'
 log.zip
```

The `log(2)(1).zip` is the annoying part.  
How this happened:

1. log.zip exists, rename to log\(1\).zip, re-rename directory to log\(1\).
2. log\(1\).zip exists, rename zip to log\(2\).zip, re-rename directory to log\(2\)
3. log\(2\)/ exists, rename to log\(2\)\(1\)/, update zip to log\(2\)\(1\).zip
4. This passes and they become the final names.

Preferably, we want log\(3\). But that wasn’t going to happen, because `uniqueDirectoryName()` always starts with 1, and then increments from there. If we strip the suffix in step 3 and pass in `log`, then it will go in an infinite loop starting from step 1. If we don’t strip the suffix and pass in `log(2)`, then it will give us `log(2)(1)`.

So instead of calling `unique` twice, I think we need to control the counter in `ign.cc`. Now it gives us `(3)` ,`(4)`, etc, on subsequent calls, which is better. It’s not as nice as using the utility functions in `common::`, but… it’s much cleaner. Now the directory looks like:

```
$ ls /tmp
'log(1).zip'
'log(2)'
'log(3).zip'
 log.zip
```

‌
content.html:
9bb7af8 & 95c56bf

So I ended up replacing the common::unique*() calls with the line of logic from unique*(). That fixed the problem. It was needed because having two unique() calls separately on the directory and the file didn’t let us control the counter. So we ended up with things like (2)(1).

Previously, the problem could be reproduced by:

ign gazebo -v 4 -r ../examples/worlds/log_record_dbl_pendulum.sdf --log-compress --log-overwrite --record-path '/tmp/log'
ign gazebo -v 4 -r ../examples/worlds/log_record_dbl_pendulum.sdf --log-compress --record-path '/tmp/log'
ign gazebo -v 4 -r ../examples/worlds/log_record_dbl_pendulum.sdf --record-path '/tmp/log'
ign gazebo -v 4 -r ../examples/worlds/log_record_dbl_pendulum.sdf --log-compress --record-path '/tmp/log'

which produces:

$ ls /tmp
'log(1).zip'
'log(2)'
'log(2)(1).zip'
 log.zip

The log(2)(1).zip is the annoying part.
How this happened:

  1. log.zip exists, rename to log(1).zip, re-rename directory to log(1).
  2. log(1).zip exists, rename zip to log(2).zip, re-rename directory to log(2)
  3. log(2)/ exists, rename to log(2)(1)/, update zip to log(2)(1).zip
  4. This passes and they become the final names.

Preferably, we want log(3). But that wasn’t going to happen, because uniqueDirectoryName() always starts with 1, and then increments from there. If we strip the suffix in step 3 and pass in log, then it will go in an infinite loop starting from step 1. If we don’t strip the suffix and pass in log(2), then it will give us log(2)(1).

So instead of calling unique twice, I think we need to control the counter in ign.cc. Now it gives us (3) ,(4), etc, on subsequent calls, which is better. It’s not as nice as using the utility functions in common::, but… it’s much cleaner. Now the directory looks like:

$ ls /tmp
'log(1).zip'
'log(2)'
'log(3).zip'
 log.zip

‌

content.raw:
Going forward, I recommend we pass command line options to systems through components, like what's done [here](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/541/find-custom-physics-engines/diff#Lsrc/LevelManager.ccT93). Creating SDF elements on the fly is a bit clunky, and we may not always want to expose the feature through SDF (like how we're about to deprecate logging `<path>`). Having it in a component also makes it easily displayable to the user on the GUI.

I don't want to stall this PR further, so let's keep this approach here. Just something to keep in mind for the future.
content.html:
Going forward, I recommend we pass command line options to systems through components, like what's done here. Creating SDF elements on the fly is a bit clunky, and we may not always want to expose the feature through SDF (like how we're about to deprecate logging <path>). Having it in a component also makes it easily displayable to the user on the GUI.

I don't want to stall this PR further, so let's keep this approach here. Just something to keep in mind for the future.

content.raw:
After playing back, the extracted files remain on disk, next to the zip file. As a user, I was a bit surprised to see that, but maybe that's just me? That means that when I playback a log, there's left-overs taking more space on disk. 

How do you feel about unzipping into a temp folder and cleaning it at the end?
content.html:

How do you feel about unzipping into a temp folder and cleaning it at the end?

content.raw: At a glance, looks like OS X is not creating the `(#)` directories / files for the non-overwrite case. That would be a problem with the overwrite function. Looks like the log\_overwrite PR’s build farm logs are gone now, so I don’t know whether OS X passed the LogOverwrite test there. Do you happen to remember? I’m just going to put in some printouts to confirm and look at it further.
content.html: At a glance, looks like OS X is not creating the (#) directories / files for the non-overwrite case. That would be a problem with the overwrite function. Looks like the log_overwrite PR’s build farm logs are gone now, so I don’t know whether OS X passed the LogOverwrite test there. Do you happen to remember? I’m just going to put in some printouts to confirm and look at it further.

content.raw:
OS X is printing this:

```
[IGN_GAZEBO_SYSTEM_PLUGIN_PATH=/Users/jenkins/workspace/ignition_gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/build/lib /Users/jenkins/workspace/ignition_gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/build/bin/ign-gazebo-server -r -v 4 --iterations 5 --log-compress --record-path /Users/jenkins/workspace/ignition_gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/build/test/test_logs/test_logs_record-f /Users/jenkins/workspace/ignition_gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/ign-gazebo/test/worlds/log_record_dbl_pendulum.sdf]
97: [Err] [server_main.cc:195] The ign-gazebo-server tool is deprecated, and is replaced by `ign gazebo`
```

There was a typo in the command that missed a space in front of the `-f` flag. That is added in 0e50f7f.

It’s running `ign-gazebo-server` and saying it’s deprecated and to use `ign gazebo`. The problem with that is `server_main.cc` doesn’t have overwrite implemented, so the test wasn’t handling overwrite at all. I removed the unimplemented `log-overwrite` flag in `server_main.cc` in 0e50f7f. I changed the `ign-gazebo-server` to `ign gazebo` for OS X in 0e50f7f, not sure if that’s the way to do it, guess the next build farm run will tell.

Oh yeah true, it looks like the overwrite tests are also failing: https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/2563/testReport/junit/(root)/LogSystemTest/LogOverwrite/

The `ign gazebo` tool doesn't work on OSX, see issue #25. I think we probably should just not run those tests for OSX.
